title: GitHub Mermaid Dark Theme Quick Guide 2025
body:
# GitHub Mermaid Dark Theme Quick Guide (2025)

Fast rules to ensure Mermaid diagrams stay legible in GitHub's dark & light themes.

## Core Principles
1. Avoid hardcoded light-theme colors (#000, #fff, pure primaries)
2. Lean on defaults: GitHub auto-applies color tokens
3. Use semantic groupings (subgraphs) instead of color-only distinctions

## Safe Styling Snippets
```
%% MINIMAL custom styling (keeps theme adaptive)
%% Avoid setting fill/background; only tweak spacing or stroke-width
flowchart TD
  classDef accent stroke-width:2px;
  A[Start]:::accent --> B{Decision}
  B -->|Yes| C[Path]
  B -->|No| D[Alternate]
```

## Subgraph Grouping
```
flowchart LR
  subgraph Ingress
    A[Client]
    B[Edge]
  end
  subgraph Core
    S[Service]
    DB[(Store)]
  end
  A --> B --> S --> DB
```
Prefer structural grouping over color to maintain theme neutrality.

## Do Not
- Force background: `style A fill:#fff` (breaks dark mode contrast)
- Pick low-contrast grays (#666 on dark, #bbb on light)
- Depend on emojis as sole meaning carriers

## Font & Text
- Keep labels short; wrap logic with subgraphs instead of long node text
- Use sentence case for readability

## Contrast Testing
Checklist:
- No text on saturated custom fills
- Borders still visible in dark (2px stroke for key nodes if emphasis needed)

## Validation Flow
1. Paste diagram into PR description
2. Toggle GitHub theme (Settings > Appearance)
3. Confirm: legible, aligned, no clipped nodes
4. Iterate minimally; avoid cosmetic over-tuning

## Accessibility
- Provide surrounding markdown alt/context
- Avoid relying solely on edge color or shape to convey branching

## Quick Lint (Mental)
- Fewer than 25 nodes
- Single primary direction (LR or TD)
- Consistent decision diamond usage

Adhere to this guide for fast, reliable, dark-mode-ready diagrams with minimal maintenance.
rationale: Ensures Mermaid diagrams remain accessible and readable across GitHub themes while minimizing brittle styling.
